As most people know, I currently work at a liquor distributorship in New Orleans. My position, which will end this Friday, was charged with creating a database of wine lists from all the local area restaurants. Let me say, there are some pretty entertaining wine brands out there. Tell me, would anyone like a glass of Fat Bastard Chardonnay. Perhaps a little wine from Domaine de Vieux Telegraphe (Yes, that does translate to Land of the Old Telegraph). The best is Toasted Head... mmmm.. Combined with the entertainment of French wine chateaus, is the taste testing. Yes, I did say taste testing. So sitting at work doing shots of new liquor, I decided it would only be fair to report what's good (and not so good) on the market today. Coming soon, we have Amaretto and Coffee flavored tequila. The coffee tequila is VERY, VERY good, definitely a suggested buy. It tastes like good espresso or cappucinno with a little kick. Don't bother with the Amaretto flavored tequila... it tastes like tequila, plain and simple, so those who prefer amaretto sours and amaretto and pineapples won't like it at all. Already on the market is the Bacardi flavored rums -- Coco (coconut), Razz (raspberry), Vanila (Vanilla), O (orange) and Limon (lemon). Yummy! Try Bacardi Razz with sprite for a nice alcoholic spritzer kind effect. Very refreshing and easy to drink. Razz lemonade is also a good choice (Bacardi Razz, Sour Mix and Sprite). Most of these make pretty good flavored martinis as well. The 750ml bottle is between $11 and $17 dollars. Also a good try, if you can afford the $20 - $30 price tag, is Hypnotiq. A good mixture of upscale liquors and fruit juices, drink it straight over ice. It name delivers because this is a VERY relaxing drink. In other venues, Kahlua has a new higher proof liquor out. Same Kaluha, just 70 proof instead of 40, so no big deal there. DO NOT try Skyy Citrus, tastes like really nasty cough syrup. It may be passable in cranberry juice, but I strongly doubt. I have the most excrutiating headache. You know, one of those headaches that just beats like a bass drum somewhere behind you eyes. A headache that makes you beg for blindness, that way the lights around you would cease to send sabers of laser-intense pain through your eyes into your brain. Yeah, it is definitely one of those headaches. I read somewhere, I believe in a book about Polynesian Shamanism, that a good way to cure any kind of ache is to imagine it, give it shape, take control of it and move it away from your body. On a day like this, when Tylenol and Aleve don't seem to cut it, I am more than willing to attempt just about anything. Taking into account that I have no relaxation music, or even a comfy spot to lay in, I think I will set out on my holistic approach to this burden. I can see the pain, a muddle ball of blue lights anxiously moving in a circle; their bodies continuously bumping into one another causing sparks of gold light to shoot off around them. It looks like a racquetball of pure energy, like a chaotic cousin to protons and electrons. There is no order other than the sphere they seem to be bound by. I can see my hand underneath the ball, a stark contrast to the blue, glowing orb hovering above it. I mentally grasp the ball, scoop it up like an ice cream scoop in ice cream. I dig it away from the innards of my head and push it out into the light. It is held in front of me now. I can look upon it with my own two eyes, watching its pulsing pressure, the chaotic paths of each individual light. With only a slight intake of breath, I prepare to dissolve this pain once and for all. Whoosh! The breath leaves my lips in a rush to nudge at the blue orb. Instantly the little lights, particles really, erupt into a beautiful shower of sparkles. It looks like a firework display for the Fourth of July. The pain is gone.

Alabama is being Alabama, as everyone has heard by now. I was reading comments on urlLink Beth's Blog this morning when I started thinking in a tangent too long for Haloscan. My husband told me this morning that "it isn't about the religion behind the ten commandments, it is its symbol as the moral basis for law, as any educated person would know." Law makers are charged with the great task of somehow synthesizing natural and moral thought into law. Many philosophers have debated this throughout the centuries, even before the U.S. was discovered. The problem lies in moral relativism. How can we choose one over another? Is there some greater moral code that supercedes all moral philosophies? Is Christianity better because we have this cool story about a guy getting hung from a wooden cross, dying, then coming back to life? What about that cool cat Buddha, huh? Or the Hindu thing with the octopus arms? Squabbling over this stone structure is like the ongoing abortion debate, which is so bogged down in moral relativism and feminism. Let's cut through the crap here: how many of the commandments are common practices everywhere? Don't indiginous tribes honor their elders? Have you seen a Hindu kill ANYTHING lately without being punished? As awful as the extremists are, have you seen any Muslim use their Lord's name in vain?? Are morals really equal to just one religion? Maybe the issue isn't about the laws itself, but about the use of "God." Okay people, putting beside however many years of whatever religious doctrine has been fed to you there are a few basic principles to ALL religions that we ALL share. I don't care if you are monotheistic or polytheistic... Pagan, Buddhist, Hindu, Christian, Mythologist or Islamist... everyone has "god" figures in their religion. They may not call them God, there may be more than one even, but they are there. In polytheism, there is always a grand poo-bah "god" that is the supreme being, like the Sun God or some such. Think about the Catholic religion with all of its saints, etc. How is this so very different from having several smaller dieties?? Oh, I forgot we have to complicate matters by calling them "saints," because the other label is reserved for only one. A god is a god is a god... just looks different from person to person. Looking from the very beginnings of culture, language was pretty limited and "god" is little more than a grunt. Yeah, I am so guilty of moral relativism here, but I sleep well at night. When did American culture sink to not teaching us how to think? I get ripped on by Ted all the time: for my liberal education at Loyola, for my capacity to think for both sides, for my tendency to think EVERYTHING through, but isn't that what we should all do? Yeah, it really pisses me off when God is referred to as the "father." I just don't see how God can be any sex whatsoever, much less a race. Do I go off going "rabble, rabble" to make everyone believe me, to force people to stop calling God by masuline names? NO. Do I force people to believe what I believe because it encompasses more people? NO. I can understand how some people need to believe God is the"father." I can easily ignore the imagery in deference to my own beliefs when scripture is read aloud. Acceptance, isn't that what America is about? Does this mean people shouldn't protest anything? NO. It means we need people to think before they go off rabble-rousing. We all need to learn when to fight the good fight and when to genuflect to the higher order of wisdom. Yes, putting the Ten Commandment structure in that building was done without little thought to others, which was wrong. Yes, people did not stop to think about the higher "non-religious" message the structure represents, which was also very wrong. Yes, the protests and opinions of all the people matter, but let us not forget that Alabama was once the state who protested in mass against desegregation. No, the warbling of the angry mass is not always right or "constitutional." Sometimes, it is just downright uneducated and ill-conceived.

Today's subject is Bobby Jindal: website: urlLink www.bobbyjindal.com This website loaded very slowly, even with a T-1 connection. .pdf files did not want to load at all. Party Affiliation: Republican Religion: Roman Catholic You will see why I mention this later. Hometown: Baton Rouge, LA Education: Graduate of Baton Rouge High School (Not sure if this was before or after it was made a magnet school) B.S. Biology and Public Policy -- Brown University Masters Degree -- Oxford University (Rhodes Scholar) He's a smart mo-fo Experience: Secretary, LA Dept. of Health and Hospitals (Appointed by Gov. Foster) President, University of Louisiana System Assistant Secretary for Planning and Evaluation, US Dept of Health and Human Services Appointed by President Bush Platform: I. Economic Development Stop taxing corporate investments. Develop and support community and technical school systems to provide employees for businesses. Stop taxing state's largest industries (oil and gas) Raise quality of the flagship research university (LSU) so other regional universities can improve too. His words, not mine. Focus tax money where it can do the most good, instead of stretching it thinly across everything. II. Education Accountability Effective Teachers Competitive Pay Merit pay for positive performance Back-to-basics Curriculum (literacy and math) Target investments Safe schools and stronger discipline (Alternative Schools for problem children) More choices for parents Prepare for success, Pre-K for at risk students Excellent education for all III. Faith and Value Promote adoption as alternative to abortion. Assistance for women in crisis pregnancies. Regulate abortion providers. Ban human cloning. Protect elderly and infirm. Education programs to combat divorce. Promote covenant marriage laws. Enforce community decency law. Abstinence education programs Community based programs Protect second amendment rights. Affirm patriotism. IV. Coastal Restoration V. Healthcare IV. Government Reform unreleased IIV. Eliminating Waste unreleased What I Think: I was surprised when I thought Jindal had some great ideas. The online resources (once loaded) were very thorough on most things, outlining his ideas then presenting plans for action for each idea. Most of his arguments make sense to me. I agree whole-heartedly with most of his education plans, particularly the push on accountability. I can see the advantage of pushing merit-based pay. While it is very materialistic to use money as a way to inspire better teaching, unfortunately this may be the only way to improve what we have. I wish he would have pushed Pre-K for everyone. I think this could be an excellent tool for decreasing behavioral problems within school. Pre-K could primarily focus on the basic rules of citizenship... ideals that are core to behavior and discipline. If children get it early, it may eradicate the need for it later. Iim undecided about his idea of allow home-schoolers to participate in extra-curriculars, like sports and band. Yes, it is good for the interaction, but shouldn't we be focusing on getting more of those home-schoolers back into the education system? I'm a bit unclear on how he plans to pay for all of these plans he has. Jindal proposes to do away with the majority of the income that state now sees. Okay, I can understand it, but what will he do to replace that income lost?? He doesn't answer this question, but then he goes on to propose more spending in other places. You also have the whole flagship thing... I can just see the UNO students with their lips curling at the statement. Others have proposed rewarding LSU (and other state universities) for success and producivity, not numbers... I like that idea better. Faith and values... oh lord, here we go. I have to applaud Jindal for not trying to outlaw abortion. I don't think abortions are right, but I know women who are desperate enough and would do drastic things if it were illegal. I like his idea of regulating abortion providers while providing assistance and education on alternative measures. Make sure those who do choose abortion are well cared for, while decreasing the number of abortions by providing help. I don't agree with the human cloning issue. I've debated on Biotechnology before and I do believe that some possible cures to diseases we suffer with today can be eradicated through human cloning and DNA replication. I think we would be better off if this was just highly regulated; only allowing for medical research, for example. For the most part, I think Jindal gets a little too religious here and I believe it is going to hurt him in the long run. While I definitely support community based education programs, these need to be more focused on teaching parenting skills instead of preventing divorce. Yeah, it is a good idea, but I see more pressing issues here. The covenant marriage laws are awful, particularly in cases where one spouse ends up cheating on the other. Its a nice idea, but not good in practice. I roll my eyes at the second amendment rights... just reminds me of what a "good ole' boys" type of state we live in. Affirm Patriotism?? What does that mean and why?? Again, I have a question of where all the money will come from. Isn't this guy suppose to be a republican? Overall, Jindal is very idealistic. I think he pushes too hard on the religious issues, which will hurt him. He is very intelligent and speaks to everyone as an equal. I don't understand how he plans to fund his ideas, so I don't think we will see much that is being promised here. Ultimately, he is being endorsed by Gov. Foster, who is very popular, so he has a good chance on name recognition and endorsement alone.

I didn't realize that 2003 was an election year for Louisiana Governor until a few months ago, when I viewed my first Jay Blossman ad on television. I am not totally ashamed to admit this, because I don't think the lack of information is entirely my fault. We all know that our state is attacked everyday for our poor education and lack of jobs. While we usually fare better than dead last on most issues (thank God for Mississippi), our state can most often be spotted near the bottom of any number of rating lists. Looking beyond the general discourse of crooked politicians and decades under the leadership of one "Uncle Eddie" Edwards, which has led us down this rutted dirt road of poverty and ignorance, I think this year's election reveals just how low we have all fallen. When I first realized my oversight, I was appalled. Here is an election for the highest official in state government and the only candidate I've heard about is Jay Blossman! I'm an educated individual who reads the news daily -- what must those who are less educated and informed be thinking right now? Since this time, I have spent several days voraciously searching the Times-Picayune Online for coverage of candidates for governor: who are they, what are their platforms, and what experience can they bring to the office? I derived this conclusion: I think Forest Gump, or rather the very creative writers of the screenplay, hit upon something: "Stupid is as stupid does." The media coverage of this year's election thus far has been atrocious! How can we, as Louisiana citizens, expect to improve our state when we can't even gain information about the important issues in our state -- mainly the governor's election? How are we expected to make informed decisions for the better of our state if we only know the name of our choices? We are truly the blind being led by the blind, or the devious... Okay, I realize that the candidates just began qualifiying yesterday, but they have been campaigning before then. They've all launched websites and begun soliciting donations to their respective campaigns. They have all developed platforms with the changes they wish to make, but is this information readily accessible to the general public.... NO! Instead, our politician's literature is filled with the schools they went to and the affiliations they have. What is this, a race for SGA president or a governor's election? Today I decided to search all the state newspaper websites until I found some nugget of info on our candidates' platforms. I began with the Baton Rouge Advocate, assuming that because they were in the capital and closer to the action, they would indeed have extensive coverage. After all, it's not like the Manships don't own or fund an entire university department, a newspaper, at least five radio stations and a television station; they are bound to have some sort of political connections (Yes, that was sarcasm). A blurb about a debate for the 2-year community college program and the earth shattering news that Hunt Downer was the first candidate to qualify yesterday was the only info I found (Damn, I can't seem to stop). Moving on, I next consulted with the Times-Picayune. I was very skeptical about this venture because of an earlier failed attempt a week or two ago, but things were promising when I actually found an election coverage link. I was at first afronted with news of the CA race, (it is just SO important to us in LA, isn't it?) but a quick scan provided links to each of the major candidates websites. I'd finally hit pay dirt... YES! Other than the list of names, there were no stories, not even the one about qualifying. So, I've since systematically reviewed each candidates website. Issues are presented in a variety of ways: from the non-existent and general to the concrete and detailed. Some candidates assume their audience is grossly uneducated in comparison to themselves, thus addressing their constituants as such. Others take the time to present their ideas concretely in a manner that can be understood by all. Ultimately, I think many of our candidates are laughing at us behind our backs. Why are a vast majority of our citizens uneducated? Because they are treated that way -- "Stupid is as stupid does." I am scared for this state if every person reacts to the Jay Blossman ad... "Oh, I know him... I saw his commercial, let's vote for him because I don't know anything about anyone else." Blossman's issues came off as extremely lofty and arrogant. He addressed a large number of issues, including some controversial things like abortion and 2nd amendment rights. His arguments were trite and obvious in their aim to merely gain the conservative votes of the state. He is purposely playing the right keys, such the good little politician, to get the votes he needs, not stating issues he actually believes. I doubt he has the ability or the integrity to lead the state in the direction it needs. I was impressed with Lt. Governor Kathleen Blanco. She organized her issues is an excellent manner, going from the general, abstract ideas of education, economic, and healthcare reform to more specific, action plans for each issue. She most definitely has more experience; she has been second in line for 8 years now. Her ideas are more realistic than most other candidates because she has a better understanding of the what and how of accomplishing change within state government. She ultimately has something that every other candidate lacks: womanhood. Not to sound feminist, but I think now is the time to seek out and elect the female perspective into our governor's office. Yeah, genderizing isn't exactly PC, but I doubt anyone can argue against the fact that women see things from a different perspective than men. Not demeaning, just a fact. What Louisiana needs now is a different perspective, and Kathleen Blanco could provide that. This view could change in the coming months. I, for one, plan to keep a very close eye on what's going on in this year's election because it's outcome is integral to the growth and improvement of this state. I'd like to see this state change, so I (like so many before me) won't be forced to move in search of the bigger and better.

I know it was childish and immature. I know this, but it still hurt because these were people I trusted... people I believed were my friends. I learned early to be afraid of things like trust, feelings, and friendship. I've made the realization that most people I know now don't like me and it's my fault not theirs. I am deeply sorry and troubled by this. I've become what I despised as a young child as a defense mechanism and I want to do something about this... to change myself into a better person. It's hard. I know this; I think we all know it and that's why we don't want to do it. I'm afraid too, because making that change will make me vulnerable just like I was when I was younger. My youthful vulnerability is what has mutated me into what I don't like about myself now. Such a vicious circle. And the control issue comes into play again -- I can't control what other people think or feel about me. I think I feel like I've come to the end of my rope on this. It's the only way I can explain why I am even thinking of posting these feelings for public knowledge. Maybe I should stop trying to control my life and just let life do its work. I think I've unconsciously focused so much on making sure I protect myself, that I've lost touch with the same things I try to hide from everyone else. Maybe I just need to admit that I don't know the answer, for a change.

Being faced with life and the possibility of death has put me in a philosophcal mood lately. Ted often accuses me of thinking too much, which is often true, but I can't really help it. And anyway, without people who think too much, like me, we never would have a better handle on the world around us. For me, in as little as a weekend I've learned a few basic principles about life that I would like to share. First, God or the ultimate higher being, whichever it may be, is vengeful and will eventually get around to teaching you a lesson you should have learned the first time around. Case in point: While I was employed by both Delchamps (through May 1997) and Albertsons (through July 1999), I worked with an older woman, Ms. Rose. Some that read this may know who I am talking about. To shed some light for those who don't, allow me to describe her. She is your typical older, single female. About 60 years of age, she lives alone with her cats and has done so for several years; her husband passed on many moons ago. She has also been a lifelong check-out clerk at a supermarket near you, or in this case any Delchamps within a 50 mile radius of SE Baton Rouge. She isn't quite all there; rumor has it that she was hit by a car in a Delchamps parking lot. She is quirky... loves her pets like children. She is the type of woman who takes her cats to see Santa (and has pictures to prove it). Now that we've got the picture, here is the story. Ms. Rose's oldest cat, named Nu-nu, was a serious diabetic requiring large doses of insulin several times a day. Ms. Rose, loving her pet, worked two jobs, one in the early mornings at Burger King, the other at the supermarket, in order to subsidize what you can imagine was a huge pet health bill. She called BK her cat money. This wasn't the worst of it either, you see she had her day planned down to the exact minute -- her lunch breaks gave her enough time to give Nu-nu his injections and if she was late, why that would put Nu-nu in a critical state. You can probably imagine the joking that went on about Ms. Rose. At the time, it seemed so nonsensical and absurd to be planning your life around an animal. Payback is a bitch. Bloomer, my cat for over seven years was diagnosed with diabetes on Friday. Go figure! So now, she has to go on a special low-carb diet (I've dubbed it the Atkins Diet for Cats) and have a small injection of human insulin daily. She has been staying with Ted's parents, but she will soon be moving back in with us (I got special permission from my landlord). Payback... Will I be planning my day around my cat? I don't think so, but it does give me a better understanding of Ms. Rose's situation and makes me guilty as hell for making fun of her! The second thing I've learned is about life and free will. Remember those "Choose Your Own Adventure" books from elementary school? In the course of the novel, the reader came to different points where he/she had to make a choice. The outcome of the book was ultimately based on which paths were chosen. I've decided that life is much like this in a way. God, or the "Ultimate", has already written our "adventure" with all these complex courses in which we can follow. I guess some might call this pre-destination, but I don't think God ultimately decides where our ending point will be; that is left to our own free will. Each time we make a decision, or practice our free will, we are flipped to a new page in the book, so to speak. Based upon our choices, we are set upon a path to a certain pre-determined end, but at any moment that end can change to another, depending once again upon our choice. This thought process is practical when applied to real life. For example, think of a time when you thought about doing something, but decided against it. Later you heard something horrible had happened to those who went, while you remained safe. This could also happen in reverse. For me, in high school I use to attend bi-weekly lessons with my clarinet instructor. Before one such lesson, I was napping... dreaming that my dad (who I did not live with) was telling me to not drive to my lesson because I was too tired. On the way to the lesson, I got in my first accident because I didn't see a car and pulled out in front of it. While the coincidence of the message in the dream and the incident were completely weird, I obviously made a choice and chose a path which I suffered for (by not having a car for awhile; and by completely sucking for my LSU audition the following day). There have been other choices that I've personally made that have altered my outcome in life as well. Tying this in to all sorts of faiths seems logical to me as well. In the Christian world, your choices place you any level of hell or redemption, from heaven all the way down to the pits of hell. A buddhist may work their way closer to enlightenment, etc, etc. The possibilities for application are endless. I am sure I am not the first person to think of this, but I am happy that I've been enlightened with the thought. It has changed my outlook on life and makes me more aware of how what I do or say effects everything around me.

Bloomer 1995 - September 20, 2003 Bloomer, my cat for seven years, sadly passed away this morning from complications due to diabetes. She was approximately eight years old at the time of her death. My senior year of high school, my mom had seen this beautiful cat on a local morning news show. The channel would often highlight animals at the SPCA shelter to encourage people to adopt. I jumped at the opportunity to skip a day of class to pick a new pet! When we arrived at the SPCA, when went to see the cat. She had a very silky black and white coat, but not a good disposition. My mom loved the way she felt, like silken thread, she said. We chose her for my mom and another Siamese kitten for my brother and me. We went home with our two new family members. Two things became quickly apparent. First, the new cat, who went through names like Silky, liked to eat flowers. Her name was promptly changed to Bloomer, and would remain so for the duration. Second, this cat disliked everyone! You certainly couldn't hold her, or have her sit on your lap, which is what my mom wanted. So, Bloomer became the cat who needed Prozac. Several months later, we garnered a new addition to our home. A work associate of mine was giving away her Himalayan, the type of cat I've always wanted. His name was J.P. (Just a Pussycat) and he was to be my new pet. Well, since cats will be perverse; things didn't turn out as we had planned. Bloomer had gradually warned to me over the last few months. She did quirky things like run her head through my hair (only for me) and let me pet and hold her on occasion. It seemed that she had chosen me. This began our time together. In recent years, Bloomer has split time between Ted's parents and my home. She's gone through several moves, a skin infection that left her practically hairless, and now the diabetes. I am comforted in knowing that she had mellowed in her older age, becoming the lap cat I'd always wanted. Sadly, I took her to the vet yesterday because she didn't look very good. She had a diabetic seizure this morning and passed. She will be missed.

My thoughts are often revealed to me through music. Whenever I am thinking about something, I can usually relate it to a feeling I get when listening to a certain piece of music. As I prepared myself for today, the second anniversary of the 9/11 attack, two songs came to me and gave me pause and a need to reflect. I read many people's reflections on where they were on September 11, 2001, and kept thinking of an African-Ameircan hymn, Where You There? , all day yesterday. The hymn is mournful, respectfully asking: where you there? Where you there when they crucified my Lord? This is the opening question. Where you there when they nailed him to the cross? The next verse asks. Where you there when they laid him in his tomb? This song made me think of my own questions regarding September 11th. Where you there when the planes hit the buildings? Where you there when the buildings hit the ground? Where you there as they dug the many bodies from the tomb of rubble they fell into? I remember the day clearly. It was a Tuesday, and I was pregnant and unemployed. Ted and I were married and living at Frenchman's Wharf in New Orleans East. He had already left for work at PCR and I was sleeping in, preparing for a job interview later that day. I got a phone call, I don't remember... maybe 7:30 or 8 a.m., from Ted. "Turn on the television," he implored of me. I was upset that he woke me from my sleep and was fully expecting this "important thing" he wanted me to see to be something like Richard Simmons on the Today show or other stupid, unimportant garbage. What I saw shook me. It was seconds before the second plane had hit; no one knew what was going on. We were still innocent, with no knowledge that our livelihood was under attack. And then the second plane hit, and suddenly the intentions were apparent. I stood glued to the television after that. I was watching the Today Show. After ten minutes, and a plane at the Pentagon.. another in Pennsylvania; I wondered what was next. Never in my entire life, before or since, have I felt such feelings of trepidation. I think many others felt the same way. Still, I was glued to the television as they played the footage of the plane hitting one of the towers, over and over. It was a destruction worse than any movie could portray. A living nightmare. Matt and Katie had a projected view of the smoking towers behind them in the early parts of the broadcast. I, like many viewers, saw the great fall before even they did. I sat dumbfounded, in shock. I somehow found the phone and dialed Ted... "The towers have fallen," I said into the phone. After that, I went about my day, an ever watchful eye on the television. I dressed in my suit, met Ted and David for lunch, then went to Saint Charles Avenue Baptist Church for my interview. They were frantically planning a memorial service for their congregants; everyone mourned. I got the job, but could feel little joy. Internally, I sobbed for the world I was bringing my unborn child into. I had class that night, and since my interview was so nearby, I decided to hangout on campus for awhile. The class was Deviant Behavior, I thought the conversation would be interesting this evening. I had the urge to call my mom; she had the urge to talk to me too. We talked about what had happened, what would happen next. Meanwhile, the students on campus all walked around in a fog. People began flooding out of the buildings like zombies... the alarms were blaring. Someone took advantage of our fear... bomb threats, class cancelled. We all had no choice, but to go home and mourn for the loss of people and things we did not know, nor would ever have a chance to. New life tumbled inside me and I was hesitant to look upon that life's future. The second song, I thought of today. It is one of my favorites by J.S. Bach, Come, Sweet Death . This is what I will think of all day today, and I wanted to share that piece with you all. I remember playing it my junior year of high school; Frank Wickes was directing. In the arrangement we played, the clarinets opened the piece with a mournful plea, "Come, soothing Death. Come sweet repose," as the chorale goes. I remember him telling us to think of it as making our instrument cry. This is not a light and frolicing piece, but a request for God to relieve the pain. I think we all wish God would relieve our pain after two years of living in this new and frightening world. Not to say that we wish we were dead, just that we wish the suffering and violence in our world today would die. A rest from war and terror. I don't know how we can accomplish this, or even if we have the ability to dig ourselves out from the quagmire we have fallen into. All I can do is pray, "God, send us repose from all our suffering. Light our way to peace. Amen."

Today I subjected myself to a lesson in French wine, particularly the vin de Bordeaux . The term claret refers to wines produced in a northern region of France called Bordeaux; it was given this name by the British for the wine's distinctive clarity. Bordeaux's wines vary in variety from red to sweet white. The varietal depends largely upon the regional location, or vineyard, of the chateau; the Bordeaux region has five vineyards: Medoc, Pomerol, St. Emilion, Graves, and Sauternes-Barsac. Primarily, vineyards of Bordeaux produce red and dry white wines. The Medoc creates only red varietals, while the Sauternes-Barsac produces only sweet white dessert wines. The chateau(s) of the region also vary in quality; they are given "rankings" based upon their quality and history. The best wines of the region are known as premiere cru , or first growth. These are some of the oldest and most revered chateau(s) on Earth, like Chateau Lafite Rothschild, which is of course reflected in the steep prices. From here, the chateau(s) are rated accordingly, with the fifth growth being the bottom most of chateau(s). Great French Bordeaux can be found just as easily, and affordably, in the fifth growth as it can in the first. For more information about the wines of Bordeaux, visit the urlLink academie du vin de bordeaux website. Drink up!

Once again, I was reading someone's blog -- this time it was urlLink Matt's Blog -- and I started thinking on a tangent worthy of another post on the blog. Matt was talking about LSU and the rent-a-win situation and it made me remember. It also made me realize just how passionate I am about Tiger Football. Many of you know that I am a Baton Rouge native, and if you don't know I've been an LSU football fan since I was in my mother's womb. Most of my childhood memories revolve around tailgating and LSU football games because my father had season tickets and I always remember going, rain or shine, day or night, like a damn postal worker, I swear. I remember Church's chicken and the parking lot of Kirby Smith. I remember each time my heart trembled as I heard the LSU Marching Band play pre-game, both inthe stadium and out. I always made my dad take me to watch the band march into the stadium and at eight, my biggest dream was to be a "Golden Girl." I was proud to boast that I knew all the words to ALL the LSU songs printed in the programs. I can still sing both verses of the Alma Mater and the entire tune of "Hey Fighting Tigers." Those were the things that never changed, that could never go sour... win or lose. But I also remember when the rent-a-wins were LSU's only wins... you could always count on them: Tulane and someone else. I remember when I couldn't sell two prime season tickets for their face value if I tried. LSU's football history has not been so great, and they haven't always been the powerhouse they may be today. The team has only won a championship once... yes, once ever! This was in 1948, I believe. Their only Heisman trophy winner was jailed for money laundering later in life (Go Billy Cannon, DDS!). Their claim to fame before the infamous Florida game was Billy Cannon making a huge punt return in the snow on Halloween. The movie Everybody's All American was roughly based on that fable, and was filmed at LSU. I remember that too. I distinctly remember the last time LSU was even in championship contention: early 80's, Sugar Bowl vs. Nebraska, LSU's head coach, Bill Arnsbarger, (sp?) had taken an assistant coaching job at Florida or FSU (can't remember which, but pretty sure it was in Florida!) for more money than he was making at LSU (which really sucked). Hallmark rolls out their ornaments beginning in July; Wal-mart has had yard decorations and Christmas paraphernalia out since August. Summer is hardly over by then; autumn has not arrived. It most certainly is not winter yet either! Why aren't there any Thanksgiving songs or cute Pilgrim and Indian lighted decorations? Nevermind, don't answer that. I think I've vented my commercial, hippie-esque schlep long enough for the day. As I posted last week, I finished the DaVinci Code on Friday and it was a fascinating book! The author weaves truth with fiction so amazingly that it is hard to put the book down once you start reading it. Was it harmful to my faith? Absolutely not! I find that it enriched it, renewed the spirit of it in some ways. The best way I can explain it is this: We are moving from 2000 years of humans needing leadership to find their faith to a new millennium where humans can finally have the ability to seek faith on their own. Does this negate church? I don't think so; however it scares priest driven religions, like the Roman Catholics. The Vatican, I think, realizes it proved something with the stories of the priest scandals: religion, the Church, the Bible, priests, and nuns are all human and therefore fallible according to their own doctrine. It's a great awakening, a Renaissance if you will, for today's society. The religion we have believed in may not be completely right, but that's okay because it is human and fallible. It is okay that we are human and fallible too. We do not need to be perfect to be admitted into "heaven." Maybe, we are already halfway there? I think the Vatican should capture that feeling instead of trying to fight their broken image. There is no way they can ever be seen as "perfect" again. According to Archbishop Hughes, the Catholic Church is now trying to rebuild the spirit and sanctity of mass with the Roman Missal thing I posted. The church realizes that going to hear a priest's homily is no longer enough anymore because many priests can no longer achieve the same level of trust and respect as they did before the sex scandals. Distrust clouds the minds of the faithful; blocking the message. But is saying the Lord's Prayer in Latin going to do the job? What about Gregorian chant? Silence and reverence? Ted will disagree with me, but I think the idea sounds beautiful. I'd really enjoy listening to the language because I believe the language itself is beautiful. I may not know what the words mean, but I feel a "passion" in hearing it that I don't get from everyday English. Maybe, this is about capturing that feeling, of understanding that the words themselves are not important; maybe we instinctively understand even though our brain can't compute. Perhaps it could make what we say or hear in mass special, like Greek for the Greek Orthodox; however I have a feeling it will alienate a few who cannot not understand. Maybe I'm just being far too existential.

I have a tendency to play "devil's advocate" more often than not, just because I find it stimulating, trying to logically make a claim for one stance or another. I get myself in lots of trouble with my husband, because he always assumes that I am trying to tell him that he's wrong... which isn't necessarily true, at least not a majority of the time. The current "Republican" generic justification for the war is what is called an Ad hoc logical fallacy, which literally means "after the fact." Remember the story: "we were going to Iraq to protect our country from WMD, but since we haven't found WMD the war is still justified because Saddam was an ass." Yeah, Saddam was an ass when we started the whole affair, and his internal legitimacy as a leader was certainly questionable and more than enough reason to wage an offensive war. In other words, whomever decided to argue for this war in the first place made the mistake of using the wrong evidence. Tell me if I'm wrong, but aren't we taught from grade school up to verify the validity of our evidence (facts, research, whatever you want to call it)? I digress. Should be the end of it right? But of course not, this is America after all. Nope, we instead get blessed with mounds and mounds of whining which have simply boiled down to Argumentaum ad hominem -- argument against man. "Mr. XYZ and his colleague Mr. DCB aren't to blame for this mess, the entire Republican party is to blame because they are a bunch of idiots, just like their idiot Texas president." Sound familiar? This is pretty much the rhetoric of the "debates" between the Democratic primary candidates. Who can make the better sounding attack. *rolling my eyes* And the freakin' "Republican leadership" doesn't get much better with their Tu quoque retorts. To quote Pee-Wee Herman, "I know you are, but what am I?" Since when did we all revert back to Kindergarten? In Kindergarten, none of us were expected to plead a case based on factual evidence. We weren't expected to create intricate arguments designed to sway the listener to one way of thinking. Nope, not until college do some people even remotely experience a full-fledged lesson in how to write an argumentative essay. This is the point when we start learning about logical fallacies, arguments that might sound good but are ultimately arrived at through false means. This is where we are SUPPOSE to learn that "because I said so" just isn't a good enough argument response. Unfortunately, we adults can't seem to get over what appears to be our trained "stupid" responses. And you know, we've all fallen for it: hook, line and sinker. Yep, we've now succumbed to making these broad generalizations about people solely based on whether they vote Democrat or Republican. We all attack each other, blaming the other for what's wrong with the world, the environment, and the Cox cable internet that never seems to work right. The letter R or D now speaks for us; we don't even have to open our mouth before the words are put in by someone else. In an ideal world, I guess that could be kind of interesting: never having to think for ourselves because we are too busy thinking solely for someone else. Hey, I know some people who could definitely benefit from that! Unfortunately, I can't stand playing that game. I have too much fun thinking to allow someone else to do it for me! Quite honestly, I'm tired of the stupidity that has been chosen to represent me. Excuse my language, but FUCK the Ivy League educations and FUCK the millions of bucks they've made. Stupid is as stupid does, as Forrest Gump said. Sure, you might have two degrees from Yale and 2 mil. in the bank, but if you sound like an idiot, you will be perceived as an idiot. Quite honestly, I'm embarrassed for the whole lot because they sound down right dumb! You think some fancy, Armani suited politician had anything, ANYTHING to do with finding Saddam over the weekend? Other than sending the troops over in the first place, absolutely nada! Could you just imagine what this whole "war" would look like if we sent the politicians over to fight and left the soldiers in the homeland? Yep, I'm chortling at the ridiculous picture myself. But alas, on the ole homeland we are in a war of words. Great, so we've decided rhetoric is the weapon of choice between the donkeys and the elephants. Perhaps now would be a good time to learn how to use our words properly, nes pas? What we all need is a bare bones basic lesson in argumentation. We need to learn how to argue a good point (RE: arguing which political party was responsible for Saddam is what's called a bad point) AND still get our shit accomplished. We definitely need to learn to realize fallacies in our rhetoric. We all need to make sure that when we back up a claim, we aren't doing it with thin air! Ignorance cannot be an excuse anymore. After that, I'd say we probably need a new political party up in here: the Republican leadership is too conservative for me, but the Democratic leadership is way too liberal. So what are we gonna do about it?

Many men have died at the hands of her father because of the unsolvable riddle he has made as a test for her suitors. Yep, the riddle is about a father, who is also husband and brother; and a child who is both wife and sister. Uh-huh, this is sounding like Livingston Parish up in here! So, Pericles is rightfully repulsed by the incestuous duo, refuses to answer the riddle and flees Antioch to escape death. Thus begins the tests that only Greek gods can inflict upon their eipc literary heros. I mean, this guy's life sucks. He marries a young, hot thing, who is pregnant and giving birth less than twenty lines later. She "dies" in childbirth and gets thrown overboard (seamen's superstition). The child is left on another island with the "wicked stepmother." In the end, everyone is reunited... happy, happy.. joy, joy. This is not one of Shakespeare's better plays in my opinion, as far as reading goes. I do think much of the drama is in the actual production though. SO, now you know as much as I do... HA HA. Okay, Thanksgiving is now over and the mass hysteria known as the "holiday season" is now in full swing. For the next 24 days, we can all expect lines and crowds at every shopping venue we might chance to visit. Of course, we can also expect to be enundated with the strains of Christmas music at all stops as well. Yes, I know that I sound a trifle "hum-buggy," but I am a retail veteran and spouse to a "Christmas Carol Lover" who's capacity to contain his caroling to only the next 25 days is nil. Decking the halls and fa la la-ing at every turn gets to be a little too much, particularly when your husband insists on sleeping to the Sounds of the Season music channel on digital cable. I digress... Thanksgiving itself was an interesting experience. I got to see relatives that I haven't seen in years. As is often the case is situations such as this, one usually has the opportunity to make some great realization about their family. Mine: my family is a bunch of rednecks! This isn't some new realization, really. Ted has been picking on me for years about the step-family I usually choose to ignore except for the one holiday we are all called to gather for. They've got that "twang" and the aptitude for spouting out the dumbest things. They all look at me as if I am some alien, the prodigal daughter or some nonsense like that. I've known this and tolerated it for some time, perhaps even become immune to it. But I realized this past turkey day, that my Mom's side is just as bad! Perhaps it was the realization of how different I am from them. During that day, they all spoke of country music singers and "huntin';" one of my cousin's had a spouse and children dressed in full out camo for the day. I didn't have any clue what they were talking about! When I did know something, I kept my mouth shut because I didn't want to seem like the proverbial "Miss Know-it-all". I'm the only college grad in the family; I've got the good job in the "city" (One of my cousins actually told me that). It was a really weird feeling. I guess my second realization is that I have definitely become a city girl, or a suburb girl at least. Sure, I'd love to have a house in the middle of nowhere with nature all around, but I am certainly not willing to give up the luxuries of Takeout Taxi and Super Wal-mart. If I could afford it, I'd own nice, sophisticated clothing and get weekly manicures and pedicures. I'm into the latest technology and educating myself on everything I can get my hands on. I wouldn't say I am particularly trendy, but I do like classy looking things and strive to achieve that level of sophistication in all levels of my life one day. This concept is completely lost upon most of my relatives I think. Sure, they are all great people, but I just don't feel as if I can identify with any of them, nor they to me. It's like existing on two seperate areas of the same shared existence. Yesterday, I went to the ER. I'd been having some trouble breathing since late Saturday night, and called my doctor Monday morning to schedule an appointment. They advised me to head to the ER. So huffing and puffing, I drove myself the 15 minutes down Jeff Hwy. to the friendly Ochsner Hospital ER. My am I still impressed with all their high tech gadgets! The wait wasn't too bad, even though Ted (who met me there) was convinced that they were waiting for me to pass out before giving me any treatment. After about may 30 - 45 minutes, I was brought to an exam room. I must say my overall experience was much better than the one with Trey back in October. I was seen by a doctor quickly, who was concerned by my lack of resin in the lungs (a usual sign of asthma). I got to meet a respiratory therapist who was so nice as to stick me twice, because "Oops!" he hit a vein not an artery. I received a nice breathing treatment from the nebulizer and took my peak flow. Next, I was carted away for a chest x-ray. This was fortunately normal. The doctor decided to order a CAT scan because he was concerned that I may have a pulmonary embolism. This is where the fun part of the day began. For those who don't know, in order to perform a CAT scan, the tech must administer a large about of reflective fluid into the veins in a short period of time. In order to do this, one is required to host a very large IV needle in a vein in their arm. Unfortunately, on this day, my veins had no desire to cooperate. After two nurses and four attempts to saddle me up for the procedure, the CAT scan idea was given up for other procedures. The nuckle of my left index finger, my left wrist, my right wrist, and right forearm thanked them for their trouble. :-) I was given some predazone, an oral steroid, to help my chest since I was still having problems. Next, I was taken to ultrasound to have my legs checked for blood clots, since most pulmonary embolisms cause blood clots in the legs. I've only had a major ultrasound once, when I was pregnant. It was interesting watching the process, and certainly less painful than the previous encounters with the needles. When I returned to my room, I had another two breathing treatments waiting for me. I felt WAY much better after them, and increased my peak flow by 100! By this time, I was shaking like a strung-out crack whore from the steroids. Damn the contraindication with Bipolar! The doctor came back and told me the deal... that he couldn't logically say this was asthma, but since I was reacting well to the asthma meds, I should just follow up with my PCP in two weeks. He gave me some more Predisone and an albuterol inhaler script to fill and sent me on my way. Thus ended my four-hour long odyssey in the Ochsner ER. Today's word for the day is CONTRAINDICATE: Michelle and I have conversations revolving around this word all the time because it looks so hard to pronouce! The proper pronunciation is "kn-tr&-'in-d&-"kAt. The word means: to make (a treatment or procedure) inadvisable. Now, asking your pharmacist if a medicine is contraindicated for a particular condition, in my case Bipolar, does not mean he or she will give you the answer you need. It is best to ask your doctor or find a reliable drug manual for information.

Michael gave me a topic to write about, one he started on his own urlLink blog . While he spoke about Gay Marriages and religious leaders, I thought it would be interesting to look at a bit of background. You would be surprised that most people assume that homosexuality is taboo across the religious board. In fact, it is not. I worked for a Baptist church here in NOLA about a year and a half ago. While I wasn't affiliated with the church (I claim Roman Catholicism at this time), it was very interesting to see how they worked. This church accepted gay people amongst their ranks, in fact so fierce was this church in the belief that all people should be accepted despite their lifestyle choices, they completely separated from the Southern Baptist Convention. For those who understand Louisiana and the SBC will know that this was a major thing. I think there is an important lesson here. Obviously, there is a moral obligation not to hold prejudice against any other person. Some also believe there is a moral obligation to discredit homosexuality. Which one takes precedence? The Bible is an interesting document to interpret. We are looking at a largely aural storytelling tradition that traveled by word of mouth for years (think a VERY large and long game of "Telephone") before it was ever documented, particularly the Old Testament. That a collection of priests were blessed with the awesome sight to write down the proper verbage word for word is insignificant because there is no evidence to back up the claim other than faith. Furthermore, like the U.S. Constitution, the Bible is a living document, meaning it cannot be interpreted literally, but contextually based upon current conditions. It's ridiculous to think that several thousand-year-old writings can be applied verbatim to today's lifestyle! That being said, there is also the issue of historical evidence of the political "tampering" of the documenting of the Bible. Scribes were easily influenced, not by some divine power, but by the high-ranking officials that sanctioned their purpose. I was reading urlLink this article on urlLink CNN.com today when it just hit me that this entire first amendment debate has gone so far, it has become ridiculous. Straight from the text, the first amendment reads, "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech, or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the government for a redress of grievances." Of particular interest is the very first portion of this amendment, "congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion." I find this an odd conflict with the entire concept of the creation and regulation of law and order within a society. Laws don't create themselves. They aren't just born of some sweat-filled dream, nor are they the inspiration that comes over a tall Cafe Mocha in an obscure coffee shop. No, laws are birthed from the moral beliefs of the society. Morals and morality are interesting creatures I think. Morals can be taught, forced, brain-washed, engrained, or even inferred from everywhere. Very rarely, if ever, do two people share exactly the same morals... kind of like chromosomes, fingerprints, DNA, or something like that. But where do morals come from exactly, and how do we learn them? The first logical answer I arrive at is... RELIGION. But wait, "congress shall make no law respecting an establish of religion," so that can't possibly be right. Well, what else is there? Did morals come before religion? This sounds like the eternal debate of the chicken and the egg. Regardless, I think we can see a definitive line drawn between two types of people with this country. The first believes they have the right to communicate with the world in a manner that they wish, despite the appropriateness or offensiveness of the content. The other sect equally believes that they have the right to NOT be subjected to the first sects beliefs. This second sect believes that it is the government's responsibility to protect us from the first sect. The first sect believes the government should just stay out of it, per the first amendment. I find it a little scary that so many people believe that it is the government's responsibility to protect us from our own lower degrees of "morality". Since when do I need the government to protect me or my child from curse words and flashing breasts? Shouldn't I have enough sense to look away or turn a deaf ear? It continually eats at me that "moral" and "religious" parents are turning to the government to assume their responsibilities. If you are offended by something, or if you want to protect your child from something, turn it off! Example: my father did not like cursing when I was growing up, so he never let me watch any movies with curse words in them. If we started watching a movie and cursing was in it, he would turn the movie off. It didn't matter that I heard the words at school or elsewhere... when I was in his presence, that was how it was because he was making a conscious decision to personally censor what I heard. He did not depend on the government. Now the woman in the article spoke of something unavoidable, something that was accidentally glanced at by her child. In these cases, it is a parent's responsibility, not the government, to explain the situation and emphasize the moral lesson the parent subscribes to. If the child is upset, good. This serves as reinforcement for your lesson. I'm truly scared because a bulk of America's citizens are freely handing over more and more power to the government. More people want the government to regulate this and that, and less people care to even vote. By the trends, I am afraid that we are heading for totalitarianism! Sure, a flashed breast or a dumb shock jock seem pretty insignificant. In truth, at this point they really are. But if the citizens of this nation continue to hand over the reigns of their self-control to the hands of our government, we will have no choice but to revert.

I was reading urlLink Bobby's Blog today, where he lamented on McDonald's announcement that it would be downsizing its menu by no longer offering the "super-size" option. I have to say that I am not the least bit surprised by this move. Burger King and Wendy's are already ahead of the game by offering alternatives to the traditional fry and a cola options in the meal deals. The way low-carb dieting has been catching fire across the country, McDonald's is poised to make a varietal coup among the dieting masses. As Ted the Seasoned McD's former employee said to me this morning, McDonald's usually doesn't scale back their menu unless they are planning to offer something new. Personally, I don't believe in low-carb dieting; its a fad that will hopefully go away soon. From my personal experience, it only leads to an eventual stomach virus. I've "attempted" to do the Atkins thing and each time have gotten the "runs" within the first two weeks. Same thing happened to Ted. Sure, I lost weight, but I felt denied because I couldn't even eat the veggies I enjoy (I LOVE CARROTS!). For me, the stomach problems and the restriction were too much for me and Binge City quickly insued. Sionara Dr. Atkins. Another reason I hate low-carb diets: it doesn't make any sense. Veggies, fiber, and other complex carbs are essential to our diet and should never be eradicated (fiber = happy colon). These types of carbs provide immediate reacting, long-burning fuel for our bodies to function. Simple carbs, like sugar, white potatoes, and refined flour products, break down quickly causing spikes in blood sugar levels leading a person to feel really energetic, then extermely drained in a short period of time. These are the carbs we usually overindulge in, not the others. Currently, I am working to reduce (not eradicate) my simple carb intake, while increasing my complex carb AND protein intake. This must also be coupled with portion control, low-fat preparation, and exercise (for calorie burn) for effectiveness. I'm attempting more of a lifestyle change than anything else. I think it's vitally important for our mental health to not restrict anything from a diet. I believe restricting food translates to starvation in a dieter's mind. We have a tendency to fixate on what we can't have to the point that we binge. As a "diet" is not something one goes on, but a lifetime eating style, I think it is important to train ourselves to properly treat ourselves to sugars and candy without the worry of overindulgence. It's also important to train ourselves to separate our emotions from the food we favor for our overindulgence. This is what I am working on right now. I have learned to identify when I feel stressed, I crave chocolate. Having that knowledge, I've been able to refocus my outlet from food to some other endeavor. We shall see how successful this method will be.

Ted and I went to see "The Passion of Christ" on Friday afternoon. Since even before its release, this film has been making news because of its reported "anti-Semitic" atmosphere and "ultra-violent" depiction of the crucifixion of Christ. Always one who is easily attracted by controversial hype, I could not wait to see the film, because I was sure it would be an intense viewing experience. I was not proved wrong. Is this film violent? Well, yeah. What does everyone think, that scourging and crucifixion was pretty? I went into the film expecting a realistic display of the violence which coincided with what I happened to know of that period. I received exactly what I expected. Was it hard to take? Yes, at times it was difficult; however, I believe it was meant to be so. The viewer is simply taken from the theatre and tossed into the throng of people surrounding Jesus as he is beaten and sent to his death. One feels every lash as if it were his or her own, as it should be. Jesus said that he died so we are forgiven of our sin. How accurate and amazing that Mel Gibson has allowed us the opportunity to share in that sacrifice. Now, was the film anti-Semitic? I do not think so. Yes, the Jewish people were extremely critical of Jesus. His teachings were new and threatening to their status quo. The responses of the masses are typical if you think about it. Not everyone has the courage to change, to go against the grain of popular society. We see that even today. Does this mean that the Jewish society today should be punished? Absolutely not! Jews today are no more culpable for the mistakes of their ancestors than I personally was for the concentration camps during WWII. I was not alive during WWII, so I could not control those horrible actions. Not one member of the Jewish faith was alive during Jesus' life; therefore, they should not be punished. I think one of the final scenes of this film is overlooked in all of the anti-Semitic debate. After Jesus dies, the temple begins to crumble under the force of a great earthquake. This, of course, was foretold by Christ, and laughed at by the Pharisees. One can see the beginnings of regret in the eyes of some of the Pharisees in this scene, as if they realize that they have made a mistake. The scene is important because Gibson shows that the Jews of that time were capable for remorse for their actions. The scene certainly communicates that they were not entirely barbaric. Overall, this is certainly a film to see if you can handle the violent realism. I think it makes the passion story more meaningful for the viewer. Gibson himself is a strict traditional Catholic (he follows pre-Vatican II doctrine); however, I think this film would be good for a viewer of any faith as just a means of a historical view of one of the greatest faith stories of modern times.

urlLink Michael and urlLink Pete started an interesting topic for the season. Of course, urlLink Eric Stoltz has chimed in as well. I have been working on this for a few days, but I think I have come up with something I can be proud of. I am very interested in hearing what my other friends feel on these different issues, so please comment away! Abortion: After reading the other blogs, I am surprised no one mentioned that the government provides 1) health clinics that hand out free birth control (both condom and the pill); 2) an aggressive ad campaign aimed at the audiences mentioned (impoverished women and teens); 3)WIC voucher system to provide basic essentials for the health of at-risk women, infants, and children in poverty. None of this is working to control the amount of "unwanted" pregnancies. If the argument is abortion is for helping children born into poverty or a situation where they are "unwanted," adoption and half-way houses should be pushed as a more feasible alternative to abortion. Provide a safe place for the woman to convalesce and receive quality prenatal care, then find adoptive parents for the child. Ultimately, abortion should not be illegal, because it is the woman's right to choose how to handle her body, her guilt, her morals, and her choices. This does not make abortion any less amoral; however, to make abortion illegal could open the door for desperate women to perform desperate acts such as those done in the early decades of last century (refer to the film If These Walls Could Talk ). This does not mean abortion cannot carry a social stigma, which for many would prevent them from considering this alternative. Abortion should only be socially acceptable and supported as an alternative for victims of sexual trauma (carrying a child would be too mentally stressful for such an individual, and leads to a much higher risk of suicide and severe depression) and women at-risk of health related problems (in certain circumstances where mother and unborn child are both at great risk to death). The human fetus is a living being from about four days old (when the developing heart begins to beat and the developing brain begins to function), so it is certainly a false claim to believe that a child is not living until they are conceived. Facts like these should be stressed via education to impress upon our youth the idea of abortion as an unqualified alternative to adoption. As for children born into poverty, government could probably do a better job of protecting the rights of children in our society. Ideas include advertising foster parenting, particularly amongst willing parents who are unable to conceive, and removing children from households that are unsafe. Families who are on welfare should submit to regular "inspections" of housing and childcare (I think is already done). Childcare vouchers should be provided so parents can find jobs or training for a job, (this is already done). Finally, welfare should be provided with birth control provisions. Government provides birth control free of charge. If a child is conceived despite this, the child should be given up for adoption. No, not all low-income families are bad; however, I believe "good" parents would only bring into the world as many children as they could afford to parent effectively. Any more would be selfish. Just my view though. Health Care: I actually debated this topic in high school; it was the national debate topic for 1994. National healthcare is just not a feasible solution for the United States for a variety of reasons. The most basic argument: we have many more citizens to care for than Canada. Bigger country = bigger amounts of money to spend to cover everyone's health costs. Next, we are a nation that does not believe in preventative care. Consequently, are healthcare costs have risen to cover the large amounts of emergency care that could have been avoided if only everyone went to see their doctor for regular physicals. Most people have been raised on the ideology that "if it ain't broke, then don't fix it," but this concept just doesn't work in the health field. Medicine can identify, treat, and cure many diseases before they present any major symptoms, so just because you "feel" fine does not mean you are fine. From there, we are quite a litigious lot, which also factors into rising health care costs. Doctors must carry malpractice insurance in order to protect themselves from the possible malpractice suits of their patients. Guess who absorbs this cost? Clue: it is not the doctor, per se. Do doctors make mistakes? Sure, they are human, even if they somehow made it through medical school :-). Perhaps, limitations of malpractice suits and the sum of its rewards would improve this area; however, based on the status quo, this creates a limitation to national healthcare. Also, our drug costs are considerably higher than Canada. For the millions who have no drug coverage this is awful, but there are reasons. Our drugs are highly regulated by the FDA, which requires many tests and focus groups before a drug can be marketed. The FDA also protects us from many harmful or unnecessary additives in the meds they regulate. Of course, this comes at a price. Guess who absorbs the cost of all the testing and high quality material? Again a clue: it is not the drug companies. Sure, the uninsured can purchase most prescriptions from Canada over the internet, but lately there have been tons of warnings about the contents of these meds. I cannot argue that this is not money well spent. I would rather take good drugs that work well, than fair drugs that may have an unknown effect. Another thing to note, Canada and much of Europe is actually benefiting for the drug research we pay for through high insurance and drug costs. Of course, with the US footing the bill, these countries can easily afford national healthcare. That being said, I DO wish our government would give particular attention to the state of mental health coverage within this nation. After the Reagan administration cut funding for mental health facilities, our nation's homeless rate jumped drastically. It is essentially unsafe for us to ignore the mentally ill; however, the psychopharmacopia contains some of the most expensive drugs available. The mentally ill have difficulty finding and keeping employment, and thus quality health care. With insurance, inpatient care is time-limited, so one can imagine the quality of care for an uninsured individual. Because of the costs, most of the nation's mentally ill are non-med compliant, which can potentially lead to dangerous situations, like murder. Most of the nation's homeless are people who could benefit from mental care. Yes, research in this area is quite expensive; however, with the proper government subsidies so many could benefit from an improvement in their quality of life. How can the government take action? I have no clue, and am afraid that again the idea is not feasible. *SIGH* Here is to hoping! Gun Control: The right to bear arms is a constitutional right. One cannot argue with that. In addition, guns do not kill people. A person must force an action in order to attain the reaction of a gun firing, which creates the product of death. This is basic logic. Until we can diffuse the condition by which humans feel they need to murder other humans, humankind will find whatever means to perform the act of killing. If not by gun, other means will be used. Decency Laws: Yes, there is a point when individuals just need to stop handing their freedoms over to the government; however, that still does not mean that anyone has the right to do anything whenever they want. That is not what the First Amendment says at all. Read the first amendment. It states that government does not have the right to make into law any religious belief that interferes with others rights to free speech, free press, or freedom to assemble peacefully. It does not say anyone has the freedom to say whatever she wants whenever she wants without regard for others. Freedom of Speech is a delicate situation because it is hard to find that line between free expression of a belief and outright disregard for other individuals. All the ratings and warning labels on CDs, television, movies and video games are a good thing that is working. These make parents aware of the content of what they are about to watch or listen to, and from there allows them the opportunity to do their parental duty and chose whether the content is appropriate for their children. Like urlLink Pete said, this is a difficult concept for radio because there is no visual element there to notify people of content. In this case, the radio DJ is really has to take some responsibility to insure that their shows are just shy of being indecent; however, who decides what is indecent? I think many individuals are being overly sensitive to decency currently, which has results in many people losing their jobs. The FCC needs to remember the democratic policy of ruling on the opinion of the WHOLE of society, not just the vocal advocates. Stem Cell Research: Problem here is the possibility for harvesting babies for the sole purpose of this type of research, which negates the lessons I spoke of under abortions above. Stem Cells can be easily attained from the placenta and umbilical cord after-birth of any delivering mother (again, it is thrown away, but the image is MUCH less disturbing). Parents are encouraged to store their baby's stem cells cryogenically as a means for fighting future disorders, but more than enough is available to share with science too! Cloning: We shouldn't be trying to clone the body, but the DNA and cell structure of a human being in order to repair the "bad coding" that predispositions individuals for illnesses of all kinds. Get that down, then we'll talk about body parts (for replacing un-repairable damage?). Lauren Anderson, friend and med student, can tell you all about this subject. I hope that she will comment if she has the time. :-) Tobacco: Banning it will not stop it from being used, not to mention, it will not ever, EVER happen. Tax it heavily and use the income for education. Make it illegal in eating establishments, but not bars (who do not serve food at all). If you are real concern is people's health, the sheer cost will cut down most people's habits, but the diehards will still be puffing away. Marijuana: This is the same concept as smoking. Use tax money for education. Damn right someone should benefit from another's vice! Other drugs: I am a little worried about the legalization of some of these drugs. These can be addictive and attitude/life changing, much like many of the controlled addictive prescription substances (stimulants, benzodiazepines, painkillers). This would be difficult to regulate realistically. Legal drinking age: I think a lower drinking age would only work if the community at large were willing to promote education on how to drink responsibly. Parenting has been too shoddy for most lately, so I do not know if I would trust the public with this type of freedom. Seems like a nice idea, but I doubt it would work in real life. Legal gambling age: I could care less about gambling. Tax it so some good can come from the stupidity of others. Welfare: Time limits are good, but government needs to provide reliable childcare while parents receive training or work. Mandatory BIRTH CONTROL with adoption penalty if a child is conceived. Regular inspections of home life to insure the welfare of children, and more foster parenting if children need to be removed from bad situations.

Back in my high school days, I was into listening to heavy metal music: Guns N' Roses, Seattle Grunge, Def Leppard, etc. If anyone remembers the time (think 1995), GNR had this pretty popular release called Use Your Illusion I and II, with such eternal video and song hits as Don't Cry and November Rain. The videos "Don't Cry," "November Rain," were like mini-movies, with the storyline based on a short story written by Axl Rose's friend Del James, editor of RIP Magazine. Sometime between the making of November Rain and the filming of the video for the song "Estranged," Axl Rose and then girlfriend (and star of Don't Cry and November Rain) Stephanie Seymour, broke up. GNR was unable to complete the saga that would explain away the story seen in it's previous two videos. The short story, "Without You," would be printed with a collection of fourteen other similar stories in a small paperback titles " The Language of Fear," in 1995. Being intrigued by the plot of the videos, and a semi-vulnerable teen willing to buy into the profit mongering I guess, I purchased the paperback for $3 in a novel "Super Wal-mart" (which WAS a new concept then) in Ruston, Louisiana (I had just finished a weekend tri-state honor band at Louisiana Tech). "Without You" was the fifteenth story in the novel, and I cheated by skipping to it first because I just couldn't wait. The story was of a self-destructive rocker (i.e. -- Axl Rose) and his relationship with his girlfriend (AKA: Stephanie Seymour from the videos). I remember the story being completely gripping as the author unfurled these two people and their battle against fame, drugs, alcohol, and their own personal demons. It wasn't light reading and at several times it was particularly gruesome. For those who have always wanted to know, the rocker kills his estranged girlfriend and then himself in a murder-suicide aided by alcohol, drugs, and god knows what kind of mental demons. So why the hell am I sharing this with you? Ok, so I purchased the GNR Greatest Hits CD a couple of weeks ago and started thinking about the short story. I have a tendency to re-read things that I enjoy, so I thought about reading the short stories again. Unfortunately, I haven't seen the paperback I purchased in years, so I thought about seeing what the fetching price for it was online. HA! This paperback, which remember only cost me $3, now has a price tag of over $200! The cheapest I found was in fair condition for the bargain of $45. Amazing! So, lost somewhere in my collection of books (or God knows where at this point) is a collection of short stories worth lots of money. *SIGH* I would be willing to purchase any of his other works, but James has never authored another work or works of fiction.

I now fully realize why they call it "house hunting." One certainly must "hunt" for that extra special place to invest in. I for one am frustrated with the whole ordeal and just want to get it over with. I've never been one to have much patience in the first place, but buying a home is something I've been waiting on for quite awhile as it is. For Ted and I, it's looking more and more like we will be taking the plunge across the lake (YIKES!) and moving to Covington. What knowledge we have of real estate and finance tells us this would be a good decision for us. When comparing the market, an 1800 sq ft house we found (brand new) in Covington is selling for $125,000 (about $77/sq. ft.). Comparable to that, we could settle for a 20 year old, 1250 sq. ft. Metairie home in need some level of improvements for the same amount of $125,000 (about $100/sq. ft.). On top of the monthly expenses for the house, we would also need to furnish liquid funds for basic improvements, like paint, for the Metairie home; whereas, the Covington home will be customized to our liking. Even with the added driving expenses, we still come out saving money in the long run because we run less of a risk of losing equity in our house. It's all very frustrating. In one case, we don't want to commute so far. Yet, Ted and I really would like to get the most out of our money since this is such a large purchase, not to mention commitment. We've been waiting FOREVER to make it even this far. I guess we shall see where we end up. Who knows... maybe a Paul and Michelle deal will fall in our lap ;-)
